datastore.h

00001 /**
00002    @defgroup datastore Data Storage
00003     
00004     Max provides a number of ways of storing and manipulating data at a high level.
00005     It is recommended to use Max's data storage mechanisms where possible, 
00006     as Max's systems are designed for thread-safety and integration with the rest of Max API.
00007 */
00008 
00009 
00010 
00011 
00012 
00013 
00014 /**
00015     @defgroup atomarray Atom Array
00016     @ingroup datastore
00017     
00018     Max's atomarray object is a container for an array of atoms with an interface for manipulating that array. 
00019     It can be useful for passing lists as a single atom, such as for the return value of an #A_GIMMEBACK method.
00020     It also used frequently in when working with Max's #t_dictionary object.
00021     
00022     @see dictionary
00023 */
00024 
00025 
00026 
00027 
00028 /**
00029     @defgroup dictionary Dictionary
00030     @ingroup datastore
00031     
00032     In Max 5, we have a new "dictionary" object which can be used for object prototypes, object serialization, object constructors, and other tasks. 
00033     A dictionary is ultimately a collection of atom values assigned to symbolic keys. 
00034     In addition to primitive #A_LONG, #A_FLOAT, and #A_SYM atom types, 
00035     the #A_OBJ atom type is used for #t_atomarray (for a set of atoms assigned to a key), 
00036     #t_dictionary (for hierarhical use), 
00037     #t_string (for large blocks of text which we don't wish to bloat the symbol table), and potentially other object data types. 
00038     Internally, the dictionary object uses a combination data structure of a hash table (for fast key lookup) 
00039     and a linked-list (to maintain ordering of information within the dictionary).
00040 
00041     Dictionaries are clonable entites, but note that all the member objects of a given dictionary may not be clonable. 
00042     At the time of this writing, for example, the #t_string object is not clonable, though it will be made clonable in the near future. 
00043     In order for prototype entities to be guaranteed their passage into the constructor, 
00044     they must be clonable (currenlty a symbol conversion is in place for the t_string class).
00045     
00046     
00047     @section using_dictionaries Using Dictionaries
00048     
00049     Dictionaries are used in many places in Max 5. They can be confusing in many respects. 
00050     It is easy to produce memory leaks or bugs where objects are freed twice. 
00051     It is easy to confuse what type of dictionary is used for what. 
00052     This page will begin with some high level information to help understand when to free and when not to free. 
00053     Then, we will offer recipies for using dictionaries to accomplish common tasks.
00054     
00055     
00056     @subsection understanding_dictionaries Understanding Dictionaries
00057     
00058     A dictionary stores atom values under named key entries. These atoms can contain #A_OBJ values. 
00059     When the dictionary is freed, any #A_OBJ values that are in the dictionary will also be freed. 
00060     Thus, it is easy to mistakenly free objects twice, thus this is something to be careful about.
00061     For example, look at this code:
00062 
00063     @code
00064     t_dictionary *d = dictionary_new(); 
00065     t_dictionary *sd = dictionary_new();  
00066     dictionary_appenddictionary(d, gensym("subdictionary"), sd); 
00067     do_something(d);
00068     object_free(d);  // this will free *both* d and sd since sd is contained by d
00069     // freeing "sd" here would be bad
00070     @endcode
00071     
00072     You primarily need to keep this in mind when calling dictionary_appendobject(), dictionary_appenddictionary(), or dictionary_appendatomarray().
00073     So, what do you do if you need to free a dictionary but you also want to hang on to an object that is inside of the dictionary? 
00074     In this case, chuck the entry in question first. 
00075     For example, let's assume that for some reason you cannot free the "sd" dictionary in the code above. 
00076     Perhaps it doesn't belong to you. But, to do some operation you need to append it to a new dictionary. 
00077     Then, do this:
00078     
00079     @code
00080     void function_foo(t_dictionary *sd) {
00081       t_dictionary *d = dictionary_new(); 
00082       dictionary_appenddictionary(d, gensym("subdictionary"), sd); 
00083       do_something(d); 
00084       dictionary_chuckentry(d, gensym("subdictionary")); 
00085       object_free(d);  
00086     }
00087     @endcode
00088     
00089     
00090     @subsection when_to_free_a_dictionary When to Free a Dictionary
00091     
00092     So, how do you know when you need to free a dictionary? 
00093     Well, generally if you make a dictionary, you need to free it when you are done (unless you transfer ownership of the dictionary to someone else). 
00094     On the other hand, if you are passed a dictionary (i.e. as a parameter of your function or method) 
00095     then it is not yours to free and you should just use it. 
00096     However, it is not always obvious that you made a dictionary vs just borrowed it.
00097     
00098     Here are some common (and not so common) ways to make a dictionary. 
00099     These functions return a new dictionary and thus the dictionary you get should be freed when you are done, 
00100     unless you pass the dictionary on to someone else who will free it at an appropriate time. Here they are:
00101     <ul>
00102         <li>dictionary_new()                        </li>
00103         <li>dictionary_clone()                      </li>
00104         <li>dictionary_read()                       </li>
00105         <li>dictionary_sprintf()                    </li>
00106         <li>dictionary_vsprintf()                   </li>
00107         <li>jsonreader_parse()                      </li>
00108         <li>jpatcher_monikerforobject()             </li>
00109         <li>class_cloneprototype()                  </li>
00110         <li>prototype_getdictionary()               </li>
00111         <li>clipboard_todictionary()                </li>
00112         <li>jpatchercontroller_copytodictionary()   </li>
00113         <li>probably others of course</li>
00114     </ul>
00115     
00116     Here are some functions that return borrowed dictionaries. 
00117     These are dictionaries that you can use but you cannot free since you do not own them. 
00118     Here they are:
00119     <ul>
00120         <li>dictionary_prototypefromclass()                  </li>
00121         <li>object_refpage_get_class_info_fromclassname()    </li>
00122         <li>object_refpage_get_class_info()                  </li>
00123         <li>object_dictionaryarg()                           </li>
00124     </ul>
00125     
00126     Finally, most functions that accept dictionaries as parameters will not assume ownership of the dictionary.
00127     Usually the way ownership is assumed is if you add a dictionary as a subdictionary to a dictionary that you do not own. 
00128     One exception is the utility newobject_fromdictionary_delete() 
00129     who's name makes it clear that the dictionary will be deleted after calling the function.
00130     
00131     
00132     @subsection dictionaries_common_uses Some Common Uses of Dictionaries
00133     
00134     You can make a patcher by passing a dictionary to object_new_typed() when making a "jpatcher". 
00135     Using atom_setparse() and attr_args_dictionary() makes this relatively easy.
00136     
00137     Use newobject_sprintf() to programmatically make an object in a patch. 
00138     Actually, you don't explicitly use a dictionary here! 
00139     If you do want more control, so you can touch the dictionary to customize it, then see the next bullet.
00140     
00141     Use dictionary_sprintf() to make a dictionary to specify a box (i.e. specify class with \@maxclass attr). 
00142     Then, make another dictionary and append your box dictionary to it under the key "box" via dictionary_appenddictionary(). 
00143     Finally, make your object with newobject_fromdictionary().
00144     
00145     @see linklist
00146     @see hashtab
00147     
00148     @version 5.0
00149 */
00150 
00151 
00152 
00153 /**
00154     @defgroup hashtab Hash Table
00155     @ingroup datastore
00156     
00157     Max's hashtab object implements a hash table ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_table ). 
00158     Any type of value may be stored in the table, indexed using a #t_symbol as the unique key.
00159     
00160     @see linklist
00161     
00162 */
00163 
00164 
00165 
00166 /**
00167     @defgroup indexmap Index Map
00168     @ingroup datastore
00169     
00170     An indexmap is basically a managed array of pointers, 
00171     but it allows you to derive relatively quickly the index from a pointer in the array.
00172     
00173     The index is assumed to be 0-N (where N is the current size of the array).
00174     You can sort the data and retain access to an index from the data relatively quickly.
00175     There is a hashtab which holds pieces of memory that hold indices that can be referenced by the data pointer.
00176     There is also an array of data pointers -- this is in "index" order.
00177     When operations take place on the array (insert, delete, sort), the pointers in the hashtab are updated with new indices.
00178 */
00179 
00180 
00181 
00182 
00183 
00184 /**
00185     @defgroup linklist Linked List
00186     @ingroup datastore
00187     
00188     Max's linklist object implements a doubly-linked-list ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list ) together
00189     with a high-level interface for manipulating and accessing values in the list.
00190 */
00191 
00192 
00193 
00194 /**
00195     @defgroup string String Object
00196     @ingroup datastore
00197     
00198     Max's string object is a simple wrapper for c-strings, useful when working with Max's #t_dictionary, #t_linklist, or #t_hashtab.
00199     
00200     @see dictionary
00201 */
00202 
00203 
00204 
00205 
00206 /**
00207     @defgroup symobject Symbol Object
00208     @ingroup datastore
00209     
00210     The symobject class is a simple object that wraps a #t_symbol* together with a couple of additional fields.
00211     It is useful for storing symbols, possibly with additional flags or pointers, into a @ref hashtab or  @ref linklist.
00212     
00213     @version 5.0
00214 */
00215
